Award.AwardTitle: IBSS-Ex: Exploratory Research Regarding the Return Home of Trafficking Survivors

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This interdisciplinary research project will examine the return and reintegration of victims of human trafficking by combining exploration of the utility of the Global Human Trafficking Database developed by the International Organization for Migration together with the conduct of interviews with returnees and with community stakeholders. The project will help assess what types of data are needed to better understand the dynamics and processes of return and reintegration of persons who have been the victims of human trafficking. Through analysis of existing data and empirical research eliciting new qualitative and available quantitative data, the investigators will help identify future research needs to understand decision making related to return, ongoing service needs, and the availability of programs to meet these needs as well as community attitudes towards returned survivors. The project will facilitate a transition to a focus on empirical evidence as a means of addressing the needs and rights of returned victims, thus laying groundwork for evidence-based evaluation of existing programs. This project should help set the stage for future work that will more accurate information about the effects of return, including both the survivors' ability to re-integrate into the communities of origin and the risks for re-trafficking. Project findings will help assess the ongoing employment, education, and health needs of trafficked survivors after they return as well as the returnees' access to effective services fostering sustainable socioeconomic reintegration.

The investigators will use a mixed-methods approach to gain insights from three different data sources. They will conduct statistical analyses of a database on 138,092 trafficking victims from around the world that was developed by the International Organization for Migration. This database includes nearly 200 items about demographics, pre- and post-trafficking experiences, and the individual and non-governmental organization-provided resources for return and reintegration. The investigators will engage in field work with service providers in Moldova and Nepal to gain an understanding of the challenges of reintegrating survivors, and they will conduct interviews with selected survivors who returned as adults to obtain an insiders' perspective about the challenges and prospects for long-term socioeconomic reintegration. This project is supported through the NSF Interdisciplinary Behavioral and Social Sciences Research (IBSS) competition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Trafficking of people for forced labor and sexual exploitation is believed to be one of the fastest growing areas of international criminal activity and one that is of increasing concern to the international community. While understanding and recognition of trafficking in persons has improved in recent years, there is little systematic and in-depth analysis of the full life cycle of cross-border human trafficking—from pre-trafficking and recruitment through exploitation to return home or integration into a new community. An area in which very little is known are the experiences of trafficking survivors after return to their home countries. This information is of particular import given the fact that many countries provide survivors with respite assistance, but lack long-term immigration relief.

The research project aimed at (1) exploring the utility of the Global Human Trafficking Database developed by the International Organization for Migration (IOM) in conducting interdisciplinary research on return and reintegration of trafficking victims, and (2) conducting pilot field studies in Moldova and Nepal to benchmark profiles of international survivors, map international trafficking routes, and understand the effects of the trafficking experience on individuals and their ability to rebuild their lives in countries of origin.

Unfortunately, access to the IOM Global Human Trafficking Database has proven impossible. The proposal for this project to the National Science Foundation (NSF) was based upon our long standing knowledge about the IOM trafficking database, familiarity with the IOM's research management, and discussion of the data. The grant proposal included a letter of understanding from the IOM stating their intent to share their database. However, at the outset of this project, the IOM began a revision of all of their international data which they continue to consolidate into a new centralized platform. They have been extremely reticent about sharing their data in its current/transitional form. We spent the entire project, and continue at the time of this writing, to be in regular contact with the IOM database office attempting to secure a large tranche of the international trafficking data. 

As an alternative option, we explored the possibility of the IOM sharing more limited data. In the last year of this project the IOM shared selected data from its field offices in Moldova, Thailand, and Poland.  We present those data in conjunction with our fieldwork findings in our case studies submitted to the NSF as part of our final project report. 

We were able, nevertheless, to conduct a multivariate analysis of data on return migrants collected by the IOM which address our initial analytic intentions. We used a random national sample of 7890 households in Armenia that was conducted under IOM's project on “Enhancing Knowledge and Policy Dialogue on the Role of Migration in Armenia’s Economic Development and Poverty Reduction." The survey module on return migrants includes a bank of questions on human rights violations which overlap with international definitions of forced labor and trafficking. Logistic regression analyses explore the factors associated with labor migrants' experience of rights violations, as well as, self-reported outcomes upon return to Armenia. Other regression analyses include a sample of non-migrants and tests whether returnees with violations are less likely to find employment or earn less in the Armenian labor market. 

In order to gather as much information as possible on different returned victims and programs assisting them, we have expanded our field research to include, in addition to Nepal and Moldova, also Thailand and Poland. Based on the foeld research and the Armenian dataset, the research team has produced four case study reports (Nepal, Thailand, Moldova, and Poland) and drafted a paper entitled Armenian Return Labor Migrants and Human Rights Violations. Dr. B. Lindsay Lowell presented an earlier version of this paper at the meetings of the Society of Government Economists in 2016 in Washington, D.C. Dr. Elzbieta M. Gozdziak provided briefings at the end of each field research to appropriate stakeholders. In Thailand she held extensive discussions with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and made presentations for students and faculty of the Chulalongkorn University in Bangkok.   She also blogged about this research. One of her blog posts  was published in the Bangkok Post. More recently, Dr. Gozdziak shared some of the findings from this study at the  conference of the International Association for the Study of Forced Migration (IASFM)  held in Poznan, Poland on July 12-15, 2016.

Our research provided answers to the following: Who returns to communities of origin? How many people return? How decisions regarding return are made? What factors affect re-integration processes?  What are the unmet needs of returned survivors? What are the challenges programs assisting returnees face? By addressing these issues, our research has the potential to lead to further studies of this nature, in other countries where human trafficking is addressed by service organizations.
